snippet: Paintings on cave walls in northwestern Spain are far older than previously thought — some of them more than 40,000 years old, scientists said, raising a possibility that Neanderthals were the artists.
abstract: Research, led by Alistair W G Pike of the University of Bristol in England, published online in journal Science, finds that paintings on cave walls in northwestern Spain are far older than previously thought, in some cases more than 40,000 years old; findings raise the possibility that Neanderthals, or even modern humans, were the artists.
lead_paragraph: Paintings on cave walls in northwestern Spain are far older than previously thought — some of them more than 40,000 years old, scientists said, raising a possibility that Neanderthals were the artists.

headline.main: With Science, New Portrait of the Cave Artist
headline.print_headline: With Science, New Portrait of the Cave Artist
